name: chicken production | chicken for slaughtering, live weight | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/7605/documentation

This dataset is a rough estimation for describing the production of a broiler chicken for meat production. The lifetime of a broiler is assumed 6 weeks before it is brought to the slaughter and its average weight is 2.35 kg. The inventory includes process emissions.   It is recommended to revise this dataset as soon as possible.

The activity starts with the arrival of the chick in the shed.

The activity ends with the end of the chicken's life in the shed for its slaughter.
category: A:Agriculture, forestry and fishing/01:Crop and animal production, hunting and related service activities/014:Animal production/0146:Raising of poultry

processDocumentation.timeDescription: date of publication of main literature sources
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: based on available literature on raising of poultry.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: the data is obtained from international litearature sources. The infrastructure is adapted from a shed used for sheep.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: this inventory is based on literature review

flow.name: chicken for slaughtering, live weight
flow.category: A:Agriculture, forestry and fishing/01:Crop and animal production, hunting and related service activities/014:Animal production/0146:Raising of poultry

exchanges.description:
based on cumulative feed intake for a broiler after 6 weeks, and body weight of 2,355kg, namely 4,074 kg (FAO, 2010. URL:(http://www.fao.org/docrep/012/al175e/al175e.pdf)

The gross energy is calculated based on the metabolisable energy requirements (in MJ/kg) for broilers, namely 3200 kcal/kg broiler for standard diets. (Nutrient Requirements of Poultry: Ninth Revised Edition, NATIONAL ACADEMY PRESS, Washington, 1994). The gross energy conversion is calculated with the average of wheat and barley gross energy-metabolisable energy ratio for broilers. This is 1.48 (Scott, TA, 1997)(http://ps.fass.org/content/77/3/449.full.pdf)

exchanges.description: producing 1 broiler of 1.946 kg emits 80.32gr nitrate into water

The required amount of infrastructure (RA) is calculated as:

RA (unit/kg reference product) = output units of reference product (kg) / (utilisation rate * lifetime capacity)

The utilisation rate is the rate between the actual use and the theoretical use of the shade.The max, under certain conditions  stockage density for broilers is stated to be 42 kg/m2 (FAO, 2008 http://www.fao.org/AG/againfo/home/events/bangkok2007/docs/part2/2_5.pdf). It is assumed this is the max. value for space use. In the EU the regulation allows up to 33 kg/m2 under normal conditions (FAO, 2008. http://www.fao.org/AG/againfo/home/events/bangkok2007/docs/part2/2_5.pdf) . We assume this is the average utilisation of the space. The utilisation rate is then calculated as 0.79.

The lifetime capacity is calculated with the lifetime of the shed (50 years) and the and the yearly capacity of the shed. LIterature review gives an average of 30,000 at the shed at one given time and the space given is 33 kg/m2. This makes 60,000 kg per unit during the lifetime of the chickens, which is 6 weeks. This makes 8 6-week periods in 1 year. The capacity is then calculated as 60,000*8.

exchanges.description: calculated with water balance. The water that does not leave the system as chicken meat and as poultry manure, is assumed to be evaporated.

The production of manure is calculated with the dry mass  mass balance. For a broiler of body weight 2,355kg, the feed intake is 4,074 kg in DM. (FAO, 2010. URL:(http://www.fao.org/docrep/012/al175e/al175e.pdf).  The broiler meat has a dry mass of 0.34 (http://www.fsis.usda.gov/Factsheets/Water_in_Meats/index.asp). The poultry manure has a dry mass of 0.38 (calculated based on dataset "treatment of poultry manure, fresh")

exchanges.description: Calculated value based on literature values and expert opinion. See comments in the parametres' comment field.

based on cumulative feed intake for a broiler after 6 weeks, and body weight 2.35 kg, namely 4074 gr (FAO, 2010. URL:(http://www.fao.org/docrep/012/al175e/al175e.pdf)

The crude protein (in % kg/kg feed) is based on the average crude protein needs of broilers during the starting, growth and finishing phases, namely 20.3% (Nutrient Requirements of Poultry: Ninth Revised Edition, NATIONAL ACADEMY PRESS, Washington, 1994)
